bramha_story.definition: Lord Brahma is the creator deity in Sanatana Dharma, responsible for the manifestation of the universe and all living beings.

origin.roots: Vedic tradition evolving into Puranic texts

appearance: Four heads representing the four Vedas and directions.
Seated on a lotus symbolizing purity and cosmic creation.
Carries a Kamandalu (water pot), Akshamala (rosary), and Vedas.
attributes.vehicle: Hamsa (swan) – symbol of wisdom and discernment.
attributes.abode: Satyaloka – the highest realm of truth.

major_legends.name: Creation of the Universe
major_legends.summary: Brahma emerged from the lotus that sprouted from Vishnu’s navel and began creating the worlds and beings.

major_legends.name: Birth of Saraswati
major_legends.summary: Goddess Saraswati, born from Brahma, became the goddess of wisdom and learning.

major_legends.name: Conflict with Shiva
major_legends.summary: Brahma and Vishnu once argued about supremacy; Shiva appeared as an infinite pillar of light to resolve the dispute.

role_in_creation.cosmic_origin: Brahma emerged from a lotus sprouting from Vishnu’s navel, symbolizing creation arising from preservation.
role_in_creation.function_in_trimurti: Brahma creates, Vishnu preserves, Shiva transforms/destroys.
process: Manifestation of five elements (Earth, Water, Fire, Air, Space).
Creation of Lokas (worlds) – Bhurloka, Swargaloka, etc.
Creation of beings – gods, humans, animals, plants.
Granting Vedas for guidance in Dharma.
symbolism: Four heads – Knowledge of the four Vedas.
Lotus – Purity and detachment in creation.
Swan – Ability to discern truth from illusion.
philosophical_insight: Creation is cyclical; Brahma’s day equals 4.32 billion human years.
Creation is divine play (Leela), emphasizing impermanence and spiritual evolution.

symbolism: Four heads – Knowledge of the four Vedas.
Swan – Ability to distinguish truth from illusion.

philosophical_significance.trimurti: Brahma represents creation, Vishnu preservation, and Shiva destruction.
philosophical_significance.cosmic_cycle: Creation is cyclical; Brahma’s day equals billions of human years.

modern_relevance.culture: Rarely worshipped today; temples are few (e.g., Pushkar in Rajasthan).
modern_relevance.ethics: Represents the importance of wisdom in creation.
